title: Are CalPers over payments that were not incurred by my wrongdoing dischargeable in chapter 7 bankruptcy?
question: I have a letter from CalPers stating that there were over payments received by me but it was by their mistake and not mine. The letter specifically states that I did not commit any wrongdoing. Is this obligation dischargeable in chapter 7? I filed an now they are still trying to collect these payments.
question_tags: Business contracts,Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy estate,Debt,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Fraud,Social security
answers:
Without trying to locate and cite all of the research I have done on this previously, I think that although the debt itself is discharged, there is still a right of setoff against money owed to you. I have researched this in regard to Social Security overpayments, state benefit payments of various sorts and for private disability overpayments and found the result the same.

CalPERS money that has been contributed is generally not an asset owned by the individual that made the contribution, thus it is excluded from the bankruptcy estate when filing a bankruptcy case. The property belongs to the State of California (this has been stated strongly by the state when a trustee tried to take that fund in a case I had many years ago). The benefit that the contributor receives or will receive is a debt created under CA law owed by the state to that person.

If there was an overpayment, inadvertent or not, the state will be allowed to setoff the overpayment against the money owed in the future. After discharge, the state can't come after the person and take money or other assets from them, but they can deduct from future benefit payments. If CalPERS owes you no future benefit, they have no way to collect from you. If they owe you a benefit though, they can deduct the overpayment from the benefit (there are rules as to the percentage or amount they can take from each payment).

Again, this has been my experience in the cases I have dealt with and researched and can only be my advice in those cases, not yours. However, I was not able to find any way around this setoff. Your case may be different due to circumstances that were different than the cases I reviewed.

The debt is likely dischargeable, but not certain. It will likely turn on how they present their claim in the case, and how far they are willing to fight it. One key piece of information about this is how much we are talking about. If the amount is minimal (e.g. >$1000) you are probably not going to have any problems. But if it is substantially more than that, you will see a fight about this.

You should get an attorney to represent you for this one for sure.

Yes. CalPERS overpayment dischargeable in C7 BK as long as overpayment not the product of fraud on your part.

See -> http://www.justice.gov/usam/civil-resource-manual-67-setoff-and-recoupment-bankruptcy Recoupment is the setting up of a demand arising from the same transaction as the plaintiff's claim, to abate or reduce that claim. Recoupment, a creditor's right long recognized in bankruptcy proceedings, is merely the means used to determine the proper liability on the amounts owed. See, e.g., Reiter v. Cooper, 113 S. Ct. 1213, 1218 n.2 (1993); Bull v. United States, 295 U.S. 247, 262 (1935) ("recoupment is in the nature of a defense arising out of some feature of the transaction upon which the plaintiff's action is grounded"); In re Flagstaff Realty Assocs., 60 F.3d 1031 (3d Cir. 1995) ("[a] claim subject to recoupment avoids the usual bankruptcy channels and thus, in essence, is given priority over other creditor's claims"); United Structures of Amer. v. G.R.G. Eng'g, 9 F.3d 996, 999 (1st Cir. 1993) (recoupment is "'in the nature of a defense' and is intended to permit ... judgment to be rendered that does justice in view of the one transaction as a whole;" "allowing the creditor to recoup damages simply allows the debtor precisely what is due when viewing the transaction as a whole."); In re Holford, 896 F.2d 176, 178 (5th Cir. 1990); In re B & L Oil Co., 782 F.2d 155, 158 (10th Cir. 1986); In re Smith, 737 F.2d 1549, 1553 (11th Cir. 1994); In re Izaguirre, 166 B.R. 484, 490-93 (Bankr. N.D. Ga. 1994) ("[R]ecoupment merely adjusts the claim of the plaintiff under the contract. Hence, recoupment asserted as a defense is not an "offset" to a claim ... ; recoupment speaks not simply to the net amount due from one party to the other computed by subtracting one claim from the other, but rather to the amount of the plaintiff's claim alone on a particular contract, transaction or event."); In re Keisler, 176 B.R. 605, 607 (Bankr. M.D. Fla. 1994) (Amounts subject to recoupment are not a "debt" as defined in the Bankruptcy Code.); 4 Collier on Bankruptcy ¶ 553.03, at 553-12 (15th ed. 1991); see also In re Flagstaff Realty Assocs., 60 F.3d 1031 (3d Cir. 1995) (To the extent a debtor's claim is subject to recoupment, the debtor has no interest in the future income stream to the extent of the creditor's recoupment claim.); In re Gross Plumbing & Heating Co., 146 B.R. 914 (Bankr. W.D.N.Y. 1992) (discusses concept of recoupment as an adjustment of amounts owed and that amounts subject to recoupment are not property of the estate); Amoco Prod. Co v. Fry, 904 F. Supp. 3 (D.D.C. 1995) (Plaintiffs have no property right in funds withheld to preserve right of recoupment until all prior debts are resolved and satisfied.). But see In re Centergas, Inc., 172 B.R. 844, 851-52 (Bankr. N.D. Tex. 1994) (Recoupment is an impermissible violation of bankruptcy policy of equal distribution).
As long as there was no intent to defraud on your part, I would think that this obligation can be discharged in bankruptcy.
Collateral estoppel is your best argument to defeat any claim by CalPers in your BK if a challenge is filed to determine the dischargeability of your debt to them.

The main issue is if you placed them on notice of the bankruptcy. The second issue is how are they trying to collect it. This is best answered by the attorney who filed the case for you. If you did this yourself, then you may need to consult with a local bankruptcy attorney.
